articles.title: Goldman Sachs sounds alarm on AI bubble risk: why analysts are worried
articles.author: Invezz
articles.summary: Goldman Sachs warns clients to tread carefully in the red-hot artificial intelligence trade. The bank's strategists say AI remains a powerful long-term theme, but near-term risks are mounting. The concern is that lofty expectations could collide with reality.

articles.title: Microsoft's new Windows 11 preview infuses external webcams with AI
articles.author: PC World
articles.summary: Microsoft is testing a new local AI feature for Copilot+. It will be rolled out to Copilot+ PCs with Intel processors first, breaking Microsoft's streak of tying new features to Windows on Qualcomm Snapdragon. It will filter out unwanted noise using local AI.

articles.title: From curiosity to capability: How Dell helps federal agencies build AI that works
articles.author: Federal News Radio
articles.summary: Artificial intelligence is a present-day imperative for federal agencies. JP Marcelino, Federal Joint Solutions Manager at Dell Technologies, sees this challenge daily. His mission is to meet agencies where they are and help them develop their AI capabilities.

articles.title: AI vision: GPT-4V shows human-like ability to interpret social scenes, study finds
articles.author: Psy Post
articles.summary: A new study published in Imaging Neuroscience has found that large language models with visual processing abilities can evaluate and describe social interactions in images and short videos in a way that closely matches human perception. The research suggests that artificial intelligence can not only identify but also describe human behaviour.

articles.title: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 2025 Ad - Arlington Dermatology - Daily Herald (Paddock)
articles.summary: According to some sources, Al is not coming to fruition as planned. Many companies who purchase early Al products for automation find it more disruptive than helpful. Even Grok, the Al program launched by Elon Musk, seems to be getting out of control too much and too often. Al projects are developed by people with limited social skills and they overstate their abilities. Al may destroy humanity as we know it.

articles.title: Supporting Native American business success means embracing AI - Cave Creek / Carefree Independent
articles.author: Chris James
articles.summary: Chris James is the president and CEO of the National Center for American Indian Enterprise Development. He works to promote Native-owned businesses in Washington, D.C., and states across the U.S., including Arizona. There are more than 300,000 Native- owned businesses that employ hundreds of thousands of Americans. They need more access to technology like artificial intelligence.

articles.title: AP Trending SummaryBrief at 2:03 p.m. EDT
articles.summary: Attorneys general of California and Delaware have expressed serious concerns about the safety of OpenAI's chatbot, ChatGPT. They sent a letter to OpenAI after a meeting with its legal team earlier this week. They are alarmed by reports of dangerous interactions between chatbots and users, including a suicide and a murder-suicide linked to chatbot.

articles.title: Resume.org Survey: 1 in 3 Companies Anticipate AI Running Their Entire Hiring Process by 2026
articles.author: Staff Report From Georgia CEO
articles.summary: Survey of 1,399 full-time U.S. workers found that 57% of companies already use AI to support hiring. 74% plan to increase their use of AI in hiring over the next 12 months. By the end of 2026, 62% say AI will run their company's entire hiring process.
